conclusion: The separation Δx between the two objects at any instant equals the time–integral of their relative velocity Δx(t)=∫₀ᵗ[ v_A(τ) – v_B(τ) ] dτ.
The separation is an extremum when the derivative d(Δx)/dt is zero: d(Δx)/dt = v_A(t) – v_B(t) = 0.
The two objects must have the same instantaneous velocity for the separation to be an extremum.
Inspecting the graph, the two curves cross only once after the start, at the instant labelled t₂.
Before t₂, v_A > v_B, so Δx is increasing.
Immediately after t₂, v_A < v_B, so Δx begins to decrease.
Therefore t₂ is the moment when Δx reaches its maximum value.
The two objects are farthest apart at the time t₂, the instant at which their velocity-time curves intersect (i.e., when v_A = v_B).
